content.title: Peptic Ulcer Disease
content.summary: Peptic ulcer disease (PUD) encompasses gastric and duodenal ulcers caused by disruption of mucosal defense against gastric acid. The two major etiologies are Helicobacter pylori infection and NSAID use. Treatment involves acid suppression with PPIs, H. pylori eradication if infected, and avoidance of NSAIDs.
key_points: Two major causes: H. pylori (decreasing) and NSAIDs (increasing) account for >90%
Duodenal ulcer: Epigastric pain 2-3 hours after eating, relieved by food
Gastric ulcer: Pain with eating; always biopsy to rule out malignancy
H. pylori testing: Urea breath test, stool antigen, or biopsy
Treatment: PPI + H. pylori eradication if positive; stop NSAIDs if possible
Alarm features: Bleeding, perforation, obstruction, malignancy concern
content.statement: Peptic ulcer disease results from imbalance between mucosal defense and acid-peptic injury, primarily caused by H. pylori or NSAIDs, treated with acid suppression and addressing the underlying cause.

explanation.intuition: Think of the stomach lining as a fortress with multiple layers of defense (mucus, bicarbonate, blood flow). H. pylori bacteria burrow into the mucus and cause chronic inflammation, weakening the walls. NSAIDs directly damage the defenses by blocking protective prostaglandins. Acid then erodes through the weakened fortress wall, creating an ulcer crater.
explanation.key_insight: The clinical difference between duodenal and gastric ulcers reflects their pathophysiology. Duodenal ulcers result from acid hypersecretion - food buffers the acid, relieving pain. Gastric ulcers result from impaired defense - food triggers acid secretion, worsening pain. ALL gastric ulcers should be biopsied because cancer can mimic a benign ulcer.
explanation.technical_details: H. pylori produces urease, converting urea to ammonia to buffer gastric acid. CagA+ strains more pathogenic. NSAIDs inhibit COX-1 → decreased prostaglandin synthesis → reduced mucus, bicarbonate, and blood flow. Zollinger-Ellison syndrome (gastrinoma) causes refractory ulcers through acid hypersecretion.

definitions_glossary.peptic_ulcer: Mucosal defect extending through muscularis mucosae in acid-exposed areas
definitions_glossary.duodenal_ulcer: Ulcer in duodenal bulb; associated with H. pylori and acid hypersecretion
definitions_glossary.gastric_ulcer: Ulcer in stomach; associated with H. pylori, NSAIDs, and impaired defense
definitions_glossary.Helicobacter_pylori: Gram-negative spiral bacterium colonizing gastric mucosa
definitions_glossary.NSAID_ulcer: Ulcer caused by prostaglandin inhibition from non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs
definitions_glossary.urea_breath_test: Non-invasive H. pylori test detecting urease activity via labeled CO2
definitions_glossary.stool_antigen_test: Non-invasive H. pylori detection in feces
definitions_glossary.Forrest_classification: Endoscopic classification of bleeding ulcers predicting rebleeding risk
definitions_glossary.triple_therapy: H. pylori treatment: PPI + clarithromycin + amoxicillin (or metronidazole)
definitions_glossary.quadruple_therapy: PPI + bismuth + metronidazole + tetracycline for resistant H. pylori
definitions_glossary.perforation: Ulcer penetrating through entire wall causing peritonitis

pathophysiology.mechanism: Disruption of balance between mucosal defense (mucus, bicarbonate, blood flow, prostaglandins) and acid-peptic attack (gastric acid, pepsin)

H_pylori_pathogenesis.colonization: Survives in mucus layer, produces urease for pH buffering
H_pylori_pathogenesis.inflammation: Activates NF-kB, recruits neutrophils, causes chronic gastritis
H_pylori_pathogenesis.ulcer_risk: 20% lifetime risk of PUD in infected individuals

NSAID_pathogenesis.mechanism: COX-1 inhibition → decreased prostaglandins → impaired mucosal defense

H_pylori_testing.stop_PPI: Hold PPI 2 weeks before testing to avoid false negatives

endoscopy_indications: Failure to respond to empiric therapy

H_pylori_eradication.first_line: PPI + clarithromycin + amoxicillin (or metronidazole) for 14 days
H_pylori_eradication.alternative: Bismuth quadruple therapy: PPI + bismuth + metronidazole + tetracycline for 14 days
H_pylori_eradication.confirmation: Test-of-cure with UBT or stool antigen ≥4 weeks after treatment

acid_suppression.PPI: Standard dose BID for complicated ulcers; once daily for uncomplicated
acid_suppression.duration: 4 weeks for duodenal, 8 weeks for gastric ulcers

NSAID_ulcers.prophylaxis: PPI if must continue NSAID; consider COX-2 selective
NSAID_ulcers.misoprostol: Alternative for prevention; GI side effects limit use

bleeding_ulcers.endoscopic: Epinephrine injection + thermal/clips for high-risk stigmata
bleeding_ulcers.medical: IV PPI (80mg bolus then 8mg/hour for 72 hours)
bleeding_ulcers.surgical: For refractory bleeding not controlled endoscopically

definition.@value: A condition characterized by ulcerations of the gastric or duodenal mucosa, primarily caused by H. pylori infection or NSAID use, managed with acid suppression and addressing underlying etiology

scopeNote.@value: Covers pathophysiology, diagnosis, and treatment of gastric and duodenal ulcers

learning_objectives: Compare pathophysiology of H. pylori vs NSAID-induced ulcers
Differentiate clinical presentations of duodenal vs gastric ulcers
Select appropriate H. pylori testing methods
Design treatment regimen including H. pylori eradication
Identify alarm features requiring urgent endoscopy
clinical_pearls: Pain relieved by food = duodenal; pain worsened by food = gastric
ALL gastric ulcers should be biopsied - 5% are malignant
Hold PPI for 2 weeks before H. pylori testing (false negatives)
Confirm eradication with UBT or stool antigen (NOT serology)
common_misconceptions: Stress causes ulcers - H. pylori and NSAIDs are main causes
Serology can confirm eradication - antibodies persist for years
Milk helps ulcers - temporary relief but stimulates acid secretion

evidence.confidence_rationale: Based on established guidelines and comprehensive reviews

sources.source: ACG Clinical Guideline: Treatment of Helicobacter pylori Infection. Am J Gastroenterol. 2017.
